newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan Semicon raises '97 profit, sales targets.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan Semicon raises '97 profit, sales targets.

text.p: Taiwan's top chipmaker Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co said on Saturday it has raised its 1997 net profit target by 60.9 percent to T$14.72 billion.
Taiwan Semiconductor also increased its 1997 sales forecast by 15.4 percent to T$40.64 billion from T$35.22 billion, the company said in a statement.
The pre-tax profit target for year rose 61.1 percent to T$12.923 billion and earnings per share were estimated at T$3.60.

"Recently, the company feels that the market condition has become much more favoured to TSMC than originally forecasted in this March, therefore the company has decided to adjust its basic assumptions and then to revise its financial forecasts for 1997," the statement said.

Taiwan Semiconductor said the company's performance was expected to improve in the second half of this year despite a downturn in the global integrated circuits industry during the first and second quarters.
In April, Taiwan Semiconductor announced it would launch a T$400 billion (US$14.3 billion), 10-year wafer fabrication project in Tainan.
Last week, rival firm United Microelectronics announced a T$500 billion (US$17.9 billion), 10-year wafer fabrication project.

Both projects, once completed, would dwarf what until April was Taiwan's most ambitious investment project -- a US$9 billion petrochemical plant being built in central Taiwan by Formosa Plastics group.
Taiwan Semiconductor is the world's largest custom maker of integrated circuits.
The firm's foundry business does not design and sell its own IC products, but custom makes them according to customers' applications.
